text: Therefore hear the word of the Lord, all you Judeans who live in the land of Egypt: I swear by my great name, says the Lord, that my name shall no longer be pronounced on the lips of any of the people of Judah in all the land of Egypt, saying, ‘As the Lord God lives.’
speaker: Narrator

text: I am going to watch over them for harm and not for good; all the people of Judah who are in the land of Egypt shall perish by the sword and by famine until not one is left.
speaker: Narrator

text: And those who escape the sword shall return from the land of Egypt to the land of Judah, few in number, and all the remnant of Judah who have come to the land of Egypt to settle shall know whose words will stand, mine or theirs!
speaker: Narrator

text: This shall be the sign to you, says the Lord, that I am going to punish you in this place, in order that you may know that my words of disaster against you will surely be carried out:
speaker: Narrator

text: Thus says the Lord, I am going to give Pharaoh Hophra, king of Egypt, into the hands of his enemies, those who seek his life, just as I gave King Zedekiah of Judah into the hand of King Nebuchadrezzar of Babylon, his enemy who sought his life.”
speaker: Narrator

text: The word that the prophet Jeremiah spoke to Baruch son of Neriah, when he wrote these words in a scroll at the dictation of Jeremiah, in the fourth year of King Jehoiakim son of Josiah of Judah:
speaker: Narrator

text: Thus says the Lord, the God of Israel, to you, O Baruch:
speaker: Narrator

text: You said, “Woe is me! The Lord has added sorrow to my pain; I am weary with my groaning, and I find no rest.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Thus you shall say to him, “Thus says the Lord: I am going to break down what I have built and pluck up what I have planted—that is, the whole land.
speaker: Narrator

text: And you, do you seek great things for yourself? Do not seek them, for I am going to bring disaster upon all flesh, says the Lord, but I will give you your life as a prize of war in every place to which you may go.”
speaker: Narrator

text: The word of the Lord that came to the prophet Jeremiah concerning the nations.
speaker: Narrator

text: Concerning Egypt, about the army of Pharaoh Neco, king of Egypt, which was by the River Euphrates at Carchemish and which King Nebuchadrezzar of Babylon defeated in the fourth year of King Jehoiakim son of Josiah of Judah:
speaker: Narrator

text:
Prepare buckler and shield,
    and advance for battle!
speaker: Narrator

text:
Harness the horses;
    mount the steeds!
Take your stations with helmets on,
    whet the lances,
    put on coats of mail!
speaker: Narrator

text:
Why do I see them terrified?
    They have fallen back;
their warriors are beaten down
    and have fled in haste.
They do not look back—
    terror is all around!
            says the Lord.
speaker: Narrator

text:
The swift cannot flee away,
    nor can the warrior escape;
in the north by the River Euphrates
    they have stumbled and fallen.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Who is this, rising like the Nile,
    like rivers whose waters surge?
speaker: Narrator

text:
Egypt rises like the Nile,
    like rivers whose waters surge.
It said, “Let me rise; let me cover the earth;
    let me destroy cities and their inhabitants.”
speaker: Narrator

text:
Advance, O horses,
    and dash madly, O chariots!
Let the warriors go forth:
    Cush and Put, who carry the shield,
    the Ludim, who draw the bow.
speaker: Narrator

text:
That day is the day of the Lord God of hosts,
    a day of retribution,
    to gain vindication from his foes.
The sword shall devour and be sated
    and drink its fill of their blood.
For the Lord God of hosts holds a sacrifice
    in the land of the north by the River Euphrates.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Go up to Gilead, and take balm,
    O virgin daughter Egypt!
In vain you have used many medicines;
    there is no healing for you.
speaker: Narrator

text:
The nations have heard of your shame,
    and the earth is full of your cry,
for warrior has stumbled against warrior;
    both have fallen together.
speaker: Narrator

text: The word that the Lord spoke to the prophet Jeremiah about the coming of King Nebuchadrezzar of Babylon to attack the land of Egypt:
speaker: Narrator
Narrator

text:
Why has Apis fled?
    Why did your bull not stand?
    Because the Lord thrust him down.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Your multitude stumbled and fell,
    and one said to another,
“Come, let us go back to our own people
    and to the land of our birth,
    because of the destroying sword.”
speaker: Narrator

text:
Give Pharaoh, king of Egypt, the name
    “Braggart who missed his chance.”
speaker: Narrator

text:
As I live, says the King,
    whose name is the Lord of hosts,
one is coming
    like Tabor among the mountains
    and like Carmel by the sea.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Pack your bags for exile,
    sheltered daughter Egypt!
For Memphis shall become a waste,
    a ruin, without inhabitant.
speaker: Narrator

text:
A beautiful heifer is Egypt—
    a gadfly from the north lights upon her.
speaker: Narrator
Narrator

text:
She makes a sound like a snake gliding away,
    for her enemies march in force
and come against her with axes,
    like those who fell trees.
speaker: Narrator

text:
They shall cut down her forest,
            says the Lord,
    though it is impenetrable,
because they are more numerous
    than locusts;
    they are without number.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Daughter Egypt shall be put to shame;
    she shall be handed over to a people from the north.
speaker: Narrator

text: The Lord of hosts, the God of Israel, said: See, I am bringing punishment upon Amon of Thebes and Pharaoh and Egypt and her gods and her kings, upon Pharaoh and those who trust in him.
speaker: Narrator

text: I will hand them over to those who seek their life, to King Nebuchadrezzar of Babylon and his servants. Afterward Egypt shall be inhabited as in the days of old, says the Lord.
speaker: Narrator

text:
But as for you, have no fear, my servant Jacob,
    and do not be dismayed, O Israel,
for I am going to save you from far away
    and your offspring from the land of their captivity.
Jacob shall return and have quiet and ease,
    and no one shall make him afraid.
speaker: Narrator

text:
As for you, have no fear, my servant Jacob,
            says the Lord,
    for I am with you.
I will make an end of all the nations
    among which I have banished you,
    but I will not make an end of you!
I will chastise you in just measure,
    and I will by no means leave you unpunished.
speaker: Narrator

text: The word of the Lord that came to the prophet Jeremiah concerning the Philistines, before Pharaoh attacked Gaza:
speaker: Narrator

text:
Thus says the Lord:
See, waters are rising out of the north
    and shall become an overflowing torrent;
they shall overflow the land and all that fills it,
    the city and those who live in it.
People shall cry out,
    and all the inhabitants of the land shall wail.
speaker: Narrator

text:
At the noise of the stamping of the hoofs of his stallions,
    at the clatter of his chariots, at the rumbling of their wheels,
parents do not turn back for children,
    so feeble are their hands,
speaker: Narrator

text:
because of the day that is coming
    to destroy all the Philistines,
to cut off from Tyre and Sidon
    every helper that remains.
For the Lord is destroying the Philistines,
    the remnant of the coastland of Caphtor.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Baldness has come upon Gaza;
    Ashkelon is silenced.
O remnant of Anakim!
    How long will you gash yourselves?
speaker: Narrator

text:
Ah, sword of the Lord!
    How long until you are quiet?
Put yourself into your scabbard;
    rest and be still!
speaker: Narrator

text:
How can it be quiet,
    when the Lord has given it an order?
Against Ashkelon and against the seashore—
    there he has appointed it.
speaker: Narrator
Narrator

text:
the renown of Moab is no more.
In Heshbon they planned evil against her:
    “Come, let us cut her off from being a nation!”
You also, O Madmen, shall be brought to silence;
    the sword shall pursue you.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Listen! A cry goes up from Horonaim:
    “Desolation and great destruction!”
speaker: Narrator

text:
“Moab is destroyed!”
    her little ones cry out.
speaker: Narrator

text:
For at the ascent of Luhith
    they go up weeping bitterly;
for at the descent of Horonaim
    they have heard the distressing cry of anguish.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Flee! Save yourselves!
    Be like a wild ass in the desert!
speaker: Narrator

text:
Surely, because you trusted in your strongholds and your treasures,
    you also shall be taken;
Chemosh shall go out into exile,
    with his priests and his attendants.
speaker: Narrator

text:
The destroyer shall come upon every town,
    and no town shall escape;
the valley shall perish,
    and the plain shall be destroyed,
    as the Lord has spoken.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Set aside salt for Moab,
    for she will surely fall;
her towns shall become a desolation,
    with no inhabitant in them.
speaker: Narrator

text: Accursed is the one who is slack in doing the work of the Lord, and accursed is the one who keeps back the sword from bloodshed.
speaker: Narrator
Narrator

text: Therefore, the time is surely coming, says the Lord, when I shall send to him decanters to decant him and empty his vessels and break his jars in pieces.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then Moab shall be ashamed of Chemosh, as the house of Israel was ashamed of Bethel, their confidence.
speaker: Narrator

text:
How can you say, “We are heroes
    and mighty warriors”?
speaker: Narrator

text:
Moab is destroyed, and his towns have gone up,
    and the choicest of his young men have gone down to slaughter,
    says the King, whose name is the Lord of hosts.
speaker: Narrator

text:
The calamity of Moab is near at hand,
    and his doom approaches swiftly.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Mourn over him, all you his neighbors,
    and all who know his name;
say, “How the mighty scepter is broken,
    the glorious staff!”
speaker: Narrator

text:
Come down from glory
    and sit on the parched ground,
    enthroned daughter Dibon!
For the destroyer of Moab has come up against you;
    he has destroyed your strongholds.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Stand by the road and watch,
    you inhabitant of Aroer!
Ask the man fleeing and the woman escaping;
    say, “What has happened?”
speaker: Narrator

text:
Moab is put to shame, for it is broken down;
    wail and cry!
Tell it by the Arnon
    that Moab is laid waste.
speaker: Narrator

text: Judgment has come upon the tableland, upon Holon, and Jahzah, and Mephaath,
speaker: Narrator

text: and Dibon, and Nebo, and Beth-diblathaim,
speaker: Narrator

text: and Kiriathaim, and Beth-gamul, and Beth-meon,
speaker: Narrator

text: and Kerioth, and Bozrah, and all the towns of the land of Moab, far and near.
speaker: Narrator

text: The horn of Moab is cut off, and his arm is broken, says the Lord.
speaker: Narrator

text: Make him drunk because he magnified himself against the Lord; let Moab wallow in his vomit; he, too, shall become a laughingstock.
speaker: Narrator

text: Israel was a laughingstock for you, though he was not caught among thieves, but whenever you spoke of him you shook your head!
speaker: Narrator

text:
Leave the towns, and live on the rock,
    O inhabitants of Moab!
Be like the dove that nests
    on the sides of the mouth of a gorge.
speaker: Narrator

text:
We have heard of the pride of Moab—
    he is very proud—
of his loftiness, his pride, and his arrogance,
    and the haughtiness of his heart.
speaker: Narrator
Narrator
Narrator

text:
More than for Jazer I weep for you,
    O vine of Sibmah!
Your branches crossed over the sea,
    reached as far as Jazer;
upon your summer fruits and your vintage
    the destroyer has fallen.
speaker: Narrator
Narrator

text: From the cry of Heshbon to Elealeh as far as Jahaz they utter their voice, from Zoar to Horonaim and Eglath-shelishiyah. For even the waters of Nimrim have become desolate.
speaker: Narrator

speaker: Narrator
Narrator

the towns shall be taken
    and the strongholds seized.

text:
Moab shall be destroyed as a people,

speaker: Narrator

Everyone who flees from the terror

speaker: Narrator
Narrator

Thus says the Lord:
Has Israel no sons?

speaker: Narrator

text:
Therefore, the time is surely coming,

then Israel shall dispossess those who dispossessed him,

Wail, O Heshbon, for Ai is laid waste!

speaker: Narrator

text:
Why do you boast in your strength?

speaker: Narrator

text:
I am going to bring terror upon you,

text: But afterward I will restore the fortunes of the Ammonites, says the Lord.
speaker: Narrator

text:

Is there no longer wisdom in Teman?

speaker: Narrator

text:
Flee; turn back; get down low,

text:
If grape gatherers came to you,

speaker: Narrator

text:
Leave your orphans; I will keep them alive,

speaker: Narrator

text: For thus says the Lord: If those who do not deserve to drink the cup still have to drink it, shall you be the one to go unpunished? You shall not go unpunished; you must drink it.

text:

text:

Hamath and Arpad are confounded,

they melt in fear; they are troubled like the sea

speaker: Narrator

text:
Damascus has become feeble; she turned to flee,

anguish and pangs seize her,

speaker: Narrator

text:

speaker: Narrator

text:
Therefore her young men shall fall in her squares,

speaker: Narrator

text:
And I will kindle a fire at the wall of Damascus,

speaker: Narrator

speaker: Narrator

text:
They take their tents and their flocks,

speaker: Narrator

text:
Flee; wander far away; hide in deep places,

speaker: Narrator

text:

speaker: Narrator

Their camels shall become plunder;

speaker: Narrator

text:
Hazor shall become a lair of jackals,

no one shall live there,

speaker: Narrator

text: The word of the Lord that came to the prophet Jeremiah concerning Elam, at the beginning of the reign of King Zedekiah of Judah.
speaker: Narrator

text: Thus says the Lord of hosts: I am going to break the bow of Elam, the mainstay of their might,
speaker: Narrator

text: and I will bring upon Elam the four winds from the four quarters of heaven, and I will scatter them to all these winds, and there shall be no nation to which the exiles from Elam shall not come.
speaker: Narrator

text: I will terrify Elam before their enemies and before those who seek their life; I will bring disaster upon them, my fierce anger, says the Lord. I will send the sword after them until I have consumed them,

speaker: Narrator

text: But in the latter days I will restore the fortunes of Elam, says the Lord.
speaker: Narrator

text: The word that the Lord spoke concerning Babylon, concerning the land of the Chaldeans, by the prophet Jeremiah:
speaker: Narrator
Narrator

text: For out of the north a nation has come up against her; it shall make her land a desolation, and no one shall live in it; both humans and animals shall flee away.
speaker: Narrator

text: In those days and in that time, says the Lord, the people of Israel shall come, they and the people of Judah together; they shall come weeping as they seek the Lord their God.
speaker: Narrator

text: They shall ask the way to Zion, with faces turned toward it, and they shall come and join themselves to the Lord by an everlasting covenant that will never be forgotten.
speaker: Narrator

text: My people have been lost sheep; their shepherds have led them astray, turning them away on the mountains; from mountain to hill they have gone, they have forgotten their fold.
speaker: Narrator

text: All who found them have devoured them, and their enemies have said, “We are not guilty, because they have sinned against the Lord, the true pasture, the Lord, the hope of their ancestors.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Flee from Babylon, and go out of the land of the Chaldeans, and be like male goats leading the flock.
speaker: Narrator

text: For I am going to stir up and bring against Babylon a company of great nations from the land of the north, and they shall array themselves against her; from there she shall be taken. Their arrows are like the arrows of a skilled warrior who does not return empty-handed.
speaker: Narrator

text: Chaldea shall be plundered; all who plunder her shall be sated, says the Lord.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Though you rejoice, though you exult,

text:

text:

everyone who passes by Babylon shall be appalled

text:
Take up your positions around Babylon,

Narrator

text: Israel is a hunted sheep driven away by lions. First the king of Assyria devoured it, and now at the end King Nebuchadrezzar of Babylon has gnawed its bones.
speaker: Narrator

text: Therefore, thus says the Lord of hosts, the God of Israel: I am going to punish the king of Babylon and his land as I punished the king of Assyria.

speaker: Narrator

text: In those days and at that time, says the Lord, the iniquity of Israel shall be sought, and there shall be none, and the sins of Judah, and none shall be found, for I will pardon the remnant that I have spared.
speaker: Narrator
Narrator

text:
The noise of battle is in the land

text:
How the hammer of the whole earth
    is cut down and broken!
How Babylon has become
    a horror among the nations!

I set a snare for you, and you were caught, O Babylon,

text:
The Lord has opened his armory

Narrator

Kill all her bulls;

text: Listen! Fugitives and refugees from the land of Babylon are coming to declare in Zion the vengeance of the Lord our God, vengeance for his temple.

text: Summon archers against Babylon, all who bend the bow. Encamp all around her; let no one escape. Repay her according to her deeds; just as she has done, do to her—for she has arrogantly defied the Lord, the Holy One of Israel.
speaker: Narrator

text: Therefore her young men shall fall in her squares, and all her soldiers shall be destroyed on that day, says the Lord.
speaker: Narrator

text:
I am against you, O arrogant one,

for your day has come,
    the time when I will punish you.
speaker: Narrator

text:
The arrogant one shall stumble and fall,
    with no one to raise him up,
and I will kindle a fire in his cities,

text:
A sword against the diviners,

    so that they may be dismayed!
speaker: Narrator

text:
A sword against her horses and against her chariots
    and against all the foreign troops in her midst,

text:
A drought against her waters,
    that they may be dried up!

text: Therefore wild animals shall live with hyenas in Babylon, and ostriches shall inhabit her; she shall never again be peopled or inhabited for all generations.

text: As when God overthrew Sodom and Gomorrah and their neighbors, says the Lord, so no one shall live there, nor shall anyone settle in her.
speaker: Narrator
Narrator
Narrator

text:

    and his hands fell helpless;
anguish seized him,
    pain like that of a woman in labor.
speaker: Narrator

text: Like a lion coming up from the thickets of the Jordan to a perennial pasture, I will suddenly chase them away from her, and I will appoint over her whomever I choose. For who is like me? Who can summon me? Who is the shepherd who can stand before me?
speaker: Narrator

text: Therefore hear the plan that the Lord has made against Babylon and the purposes that he has formed against the land of the Chaldeans: Surely the little ones of the flock shall be dragged away; surely the fold shall be appalled at their fate.

text: At the sound of the capture of Babylon the earth shall tremble, and a cry shall be heard among the nations.

text:
Thus says the Lord:
I am going to stir up a destructive wind

    and against the inhabitants of Leb-qamai,

text:
and I will send winnowers to Babylon,

speaker: Narrator

text:
Let not the archer bend his bow,

text:
They shall fall down slain in the land of the Chaldeans

speaker: Narrator

text:
Indeed, Israel and Judah have not been forsaken
    by their God, the Lord of hosts,
though their land is full of guilt
    before the Holy One of Israel.
speaker: Narrator
Narrator

text:
Babylon was a golden cup in the Lord’s hand,
    making all the earth drunken;
the nations drank of her wine,
    and so the nations went mad.
speaker: Narrator
Narrator

text:
We tried to heal Babylon,
    but she could not be healed.
Forsake her, and let each of us go
    to our own country,
for her judgment has reached up to heaven
    and has been lifted up even to the skies.
speaker: Narrator
Narrator

text:
Sharpen the arrows!
    Fill the quivers!
The Lord has stirred up the spirit of the kings of the Medes because his purpose concerning Babylon is to destroy it, for that is the vengeance of the Lord, vengeance for his temple.
speaker: Narrator
Narrator

text:
You who live by mighty waters,
    rich in treasures,
your end has come;
    the thread of your life is cut.
speaker: Narrator

text:
The Lord of hosts has sworn by himself:
Surely I will fill you with troops like a swarm of locusts,
    and they shall raise a shout of victory over you.
speaker: Narrator

text:
It is he who made the earth by his power,
    who established the world by his wisdom
and by his understanding stretched out the heavens.
speaker: Narrator

text:
When he utters his voice there is a tumult of waters in the heavens,
    and he makes the mist rise from the ends of the earth.
He makes lightnings for the rain,
    and he brings out the wind from his storehouses.
speaker: Narrator
Narrator

text:
They are worthless, a work of delusion;
    at the time of their punishment they shall perish.
speaker: Narrator
Narrator
Narrator

with you I smash the horse and its rider;
    with you I smash the chariot and the charioteer;
speaker: Narrator
Narrator
Narrator

speaker: Narrator

text:
I am against you, O destroying mountain,

    that destroys the whole earth;
I will stretch out my hand against you
    and roll you down from the crags
    and make you a burned-out mountain.
speaker: Narrator

text:
No stone shall be taken from you for a corner
    and no stone for a foundation,
but you shall be a perpetual waste,

speaker: Narrator
Narrator

text:
Prepare the nations for war against her,
    the kings of the Medes, with their governors and deputies,
    and every land under their dominion.
speaker: Narrator

text:
The land trembles and writhes,
    for the Lord’s purposes against Babylon stand,
to make the land of Babylon a desolation,
    without inhabitant.
speaker: Narrator
Narrator

text:
One runner runs to meet another,
    and one messenger to meet another,
to tell the king of Babylon
    that his city is taken from end to end:
speaker: Narrator

text:
the fords have been seized,
    the marshes have been burned with fire,
    and the soldiers are in panic.
speaker: Narrator

text:
For thus says the Lord of hosts, the God of Israel:
Daughter Babylon is like a threshing floor
    at the time when it is trodden;
yet a little while
    and the time of her harvest will come.
speaker: Narrator
Narrator

text:
May my torn flesh be avenged on Babylon,”
    the inhabitants of Zion shall say.
“May my blood be avenged on the inhabitants of Chaldea,”

speaker: Narrator

text:
Therefore thus says the Lord:
I am going to defend your cause
    and take vengeance for you.
I will dry up her sea
    and make her fountain dry,
speaker: Narrator

text:
and Babylon shall become a heap of ruins,
    a den of jackals,
an object of horror and of hissing,

speaker: Narrator

text:
Like lions they shall roar together;
    they shall growl like lions’ whelps.
speaker: Narrator

text:
When they are inflamed, I will set out their drink

and then sleep a perpetual sleep

speaker: Narrator

text:
I will bring them down like lambs to the slaughter,
    like rams and goats.
speaker: Narrator

text:
How Sheshach is taken;
    the pride of the whole earth seized!
How Babylon has become
    an object of horror among the nations!
speaker: Narrator

text:
The sea has risen over Babylon;
    she has been covered by its tumultuous waves.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Her cities have become an object of horror,
    a land of drought and a desert,
a land in which no one lives
    and through which no mortal passes.
speaker: Narrator

text:
I will punish Bel in Babylon
    and make him disgorge what he has swallowed.
The nations shall no longer stream to him;

speaker: Narrator

text:
Come out of her, my people!
    Save your lives, each of you,
    from the fierce anger of the Lord!
speaker: Narrator

text:
Do not be fainthearted or fearful
    at the rumors heard in the land—
one year one rumor comes,
    the next year another,
rumors of violence in the land
    and of ruler against ruler.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Assuredly, the days are coming
    when I will punish the images of Babylon;
her whole land shall be put to shame,
    and all her slain shall fall in her midst.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Then the heavens and the earth
    and all that is in them
shall shout for joy over Babylon,
    for the destroyers shall come against her out of the north,

speaker: Narrator

text:
Babylon must fall for the slain of Israel,

speaker: Narrator

text:
You survivors of the sword,
    go; do not linger!
Remember the Lord in a distant land,
    and let Jerusalem come into your mind:
speaker: Narrator

text:
We are put to shame, for we have heard insults;
    dishonor has covered our faces,
for aliens have come
    into the holy places of the Lord’s house.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Therefore the time is surely coming, says the Lord,
    when I will punish her idols,
and through all her land
    the wounded shall groan.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Though Babylon should mount up to heaven,
    and though she should fortify her strong height,
from me destroyers would come upon her,

speaker: Narrator

text:
Listen!—a cry from Babylon!
    A great crashing from the land of the Chaldeans!
speaker: Narrator

text:
For the Lord is laying Babylon waste
    and stilling her loud clamor.
Their waves roar like mighty waters;
    the sound of their clamor resounds,
speaker: Narrator
Narrator

text:
I will make her officials and her sages drunk,
    also her governors, her deputies, and her warriors;
they shall sleep a perpetual sleep and never wake,
    says the King, whose name is the Lord of hosts.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Thus says the Lord of hosts:
The broad wall of Babylon
    shall be leveled to the ground,
and her high gates
    shall be burned with fire.
The peoples exhaust themselves for nothing,
    the nations only for fire,
    and they have become weary.
speaker: Narrator

text: The word that the prophet Jeremiah commanded Seraiah son of Neriah son of Mahseiah, when he went with King Zedekiah of Judah to Babylon, in the fourth year of his reign. Seraiah was the quartermaster.
speaker: Narrator

text: Jeremiah wrote in a scroll all the disasters that would come on Babylon, all these words that are written concerning Babylon.
speaker: Narrator

text: And Jeremiah said to Seraiah: “When you come to Babylon, see that you read all these words,
speaker: Narrator

text: and say, ‘O Lord, you yourself threatened to destroy this place so that neither humans nor animals shall live in it, and it shall be desolate forever.’
speaker: Narrator

text: When you finish reading this scroll, tie a stone to it, and throw it into the middle of the Euphrates,
speaker: Narrator

text:
and say, ‘Thus shall Babylon sink, to rise no more, because of the disasters that I am bringing on her.’ ”
Thus far are the words of Jeremiah.
speaker: Narrator

text: Zedekiah was twenty-one years old when he began to reign; he reigned eleven years in Jerusalem. His mother’s name was Hamutal daughter of Jeremiah of Libnah.
speaker: Narrator

text: He did what was evil in the sight of the Lord, just as Jehoiakim had done.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Indeed, Jerusalem and Judah so angered the Lord that he expelled them from his presence.
Zedekiah rebelled against the king of Babylon.
speaker: Narrator

text: And in the ninth year of his reign, in the tenth month, on the tenth day of the month, King Nebuchadrezzar of Babylon came with all his army against Jerusalem, and they laid siege to it; they built siegeworks against it all around.
speaker: Narrator

text: So the city was besieged until the eleventh year of King Zedekiah.
speaker: Narrator

text: On the ninth day of the fourth month the famine became so severe in the city that there was no food for the people of the land.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then a breach was made in the city wall, and all the soldiers fled and went out from the city by night by the way of the gate between the two walls, by the King’s Garden, though the Chaldeans were all around the city. They went in the direction of the Arabah.
speaker: Narrator

text: But the army of the Chaldeans pursued the king and overtook Zedekiah in the plains of Jericho, and all his army was scattered, deserting him.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then they captured the king and brought him up to the king of Babylon at Riblah in the land of Hamath, and he passed sentence on him.
speaker: Narrator

text: The king of Babylon killed the sons of Zedekiah before his eyes and also killed all the officers of Judah at Riblah.
speaker: Narrator

text: He put out the eyes of Zedekiah and bound him in fetters, and the king of Babylon took him to Babylon and put him in prison until the day of his death.
speaker: Narrator

text: In the fifth month, on the tenth day of the month—which was the nineteenth year of King Nebuchadrezzar, king of Babylon—Nebuzaradan, the captain of the bodyguard who served the king of Babylon, entered Jerusalem.
speaker: Narrator

text: He burned the house of the Lord, the king’s house, and all the houses of Jerusalem; every great house he burned down.
speaker: Narrator

text: All the army of the Chaldeans who were with the captain of the guard broke down all the walls around Jerusalem.
speaker: Narrator

text: Nebuzaradan the captain of the guard carried into exile some of the poorest of the people and the rest of the people who were left in the city and the deserters who had defected to the king of Babylon, together with the rest of the artisans.
speaker: Narrator

text: But Nebuzaradan the captain of the guard left some of the poorest people of the land to be vinedressers and tillers of the soil.
speaker: Narrator

text: The pillars of bronze that were in the house of the Lord, and the stands and the bronze sea that were in the house of the Lord, the Chaldeans broke in pieces and carried all the bronze to Babylon.
speaker: Narrator

text: They took away the pots, the shovels, the snuffers, the basins, the ladles, and all the vessels of bronze used in the temple service.
speaker: Narrator

text: The captain of the guard took away the small bowls also, the firepans, the basins, the pots, the lampstands, the ladles, and the bowls for libation, both those of gold and those of silver.
speaker: Narrator

text: As for the two pillars, the one sea, the twelve bronze bulls that were under the stands, which King Solomon had made for the house of the Lord, the bronze of all these vessels was beyond weighing.
speaker: Narrator

text: As for the pillars, the height of the one pillar was eighteen cubits; its circumference was twelve cubits; it was hollow, and its thickness was four fingers.
speaker: Narrator

text: Upon it was a capital of bronze; the height of the capital was five cubits; latticework and pomegranates, all of bronze, encircled the top of the capital. And the second pillar had the same, with pomegranates.
speaker: Narrator

text: There were ninety-six pomegranates on the sides; all the pomegranates encircling the latticework numbered one hundred.
speaker: Narrator

text: The captain of the guard took the chief priest Seraiah, the second priest Zephaniah, and the three guardians of the threshold.
speaker: Narrator

text: From the city he took an officer who had been in command of the soldiers, seven men of the king’s council who were found in the city; the secretary of the commander of the army who mustered the people of the land; and sixty men of the people of the land who were found inside the city.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then Nebuzaradan the captain of the guard took them and brought them to the king of Babylon at Riblah.
speaker: Narrator

text: And the king of Babylon struck them down and put them to death at Riblah in the land of Hamath. So Judah went into exile out of its land.
speaker: Narrator

text: This is the number of the people whom Nebuchadrezzar took into exile: in the seventh year, three thousand twenty-three Judeans;
speaker: Narrator

text: in the eighteenth year of Nebuchadrezzar he took into exile from Jerusalem eight hundred thirty-two persons;
speaker: Narrator

text: in the twenty-third year of Nebuchadrezzar, Nebuzaradan the captain of the guard took into exile of the Judeans seven hundred forty-five persons; all the persons were four thousand six hundred.
speaker: Narrator

text: In the thirty-seventh year of the exile of King Jehoiachin of Judah, in the twelfth month, on the twenty-fifth day of the month, King Evil-merodach of Babylon, in the year he began to reign, showed favor to King Jehoiachin of Judah and brought him out of prison;
speaker: Narrator

text: he spoke kindly to him and gave him a seat above the seats of the other kings who were with him in Babylon.
speaker: Narrator

text: So Jehoiachin put aside his prison clothes, and every day of his life he dined regularly at the king’s table.
speaker: Narrator

text: For his allowance, a regular daily allowance was given him by the king of Babylon, as long as he lived, up to the day of his death.
speaker: Narrator
